Dear Ms. Jenovai:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/23/2023. The Exit conference was held with you on 8/24/2023. Due to the violations
of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
One of eight new staff records reviewed did not show proof of the educational
training or associate degree required by the staff's job description.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(d) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
In one of three special evaluations reviewed the investigation revealed the family
had not disclosed that the foster mother had increased her therapeutic sessions as
of August 2022. Additionally, that she and her husband were involved in marriage
counseling. The lack of earlier reporting by the foster family was not documented as
such in the special evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.

(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report that includes
all of the following information:
(e) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
In one of three special evaluations reviewed the investigation revealed the foster
family had not reported household situational changes related to the foster mother’s
therapeutic intervention change and marriage counseling. This lack of earlier
reporting by the foster parent regarding her/their household changes was a foster
home rule violation and it was not indicated as such in the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
Two of three special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that the
special evaluation was provided to the family within 10 days of its respective
1/24/2023 and 7/21/2023 completion date.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has
a right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this
rule.
Two of three special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of (b) as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care
up to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
Three of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
as required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Three of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (b)
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All of the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin
within 30 calendar days of placement.
One of eight open foster child records received did not show all current
immunizations for the child. The child's HIB, Polio, and DTP/DTaP/DT/Td/Tdap
immunizations were overdue 6/13/2023, 7/13/2023 and 8/9/2023 respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 18 updated service plans reviewed (related to one of eight open foster child
records reviewed) showed the child's 7/22/2022-10/4/2022 service plan was
completed over two months late on 12/6/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:

(g) A child bhavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be used
by the foster parents.
Three of 18 updated service plans reviewed (related to one of eight open foster child
records reviewed) did not show documentation of the specific behavior support plan
to be used by the foster parent for this child.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of an August 2022 visit with the child and caregiver in the child’s
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
Four of four adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not show compliance:
• Three did not show documentation the family received the DHS-612
evaluation and or the 3130 adoptive family evaluation.
• One other showed the family was provided the respective adoptive
evaluations over a month after the adoptive evaluations' completion dates.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
FOM 722-6B Family Team meeting
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers,
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.

Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance related to
22 service plans reviewed:
• One child's 7/7/2022-10/4/2022 and 10/5/2022-12/23/2022 USP did not show
documentation of an FTM for the reported periods.
• A second child's 10/8/2022-1/5/2023 USP did not show documentation of an
FTM for the period.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and signature:

open foster child records reviewed) did not show
compliance:
One child's:

A second child's:
• 7/7/2022-10/4/2022 and 10/5/2022-12/23/2022
treatment plan did not show documentation of the
caregiver's signature. Nor the birth father's
signature until 7/72023.
• 12/24/2022-3/23/2023 treatment plan did not
show documentation of the birth mother's
signature. Nor documentation of the caregiver's
and birth father's signature until 6/20/2023 and
7/7/2023 respectively.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021, cited
under 722-8C.
FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.

Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's record did not show documentation of a September 2022 or May
2023 updated medical passport.
• A second child's record did not show documentation of an initial medical
passport being completed/ provided to the caregiver related to the child’s
4/26/2023 date of placement.
• A third child's record did not show documentation of updated medical
passports for 2022.
Repeat Violation-Interim 2022, Renewal 2021- Cited under ISEP-6.49.
ADM 300 Child adoption assessment and adoption addendum.
Child Adoption Assessment Timeframes:
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
Child adoption assessment addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not been
placed for adoption.
Two of six open child adoption records reviewed, and one of four adoption
placement records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's child adoption assessment was due by 2/24/2023 and was
completed six days late on 3/2/2023.
• A second child's child adoption assessment addendum was due by 2/6/2023
and was completed late on 5/5/2023.
• A third child's child adoption assessment addendum was due by 1/28/2023
and was completed late on 3/28/2023.
ADM 330 Quarterly progress report.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be
completed each quarter.
Two of six open adoption records reviewed, and two of four adoption placement
records reviewed (related to 27 quarterly progress reports reviewed) did not show
compliance:
did not show compliance:
• One child's quarterly progress report was due by 6/2/2023 and was
completed late on 7/31/2023 or 8/7/2023(discrepancy dates indicated).

• A second child's record showed the child's quarterly progress report due for
March 2023 was completed late on 4/25/2023.
• A third child's 3/15/2023-6/13/2023 quarterly progress report was completed
late on 6/21/2023.
Repeat Violation-Interim 2022- Renewal 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12327(7) Special evaluation:
• The agency was apprised it must clearly and consistently indicate when and
how all workers who had children placed in the foster home were notified of
the foster parent's corrective action plan and the requirements of the plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans-Agreement and signature.
• The agency was advised listing the date it mailed the treatment plan, and the
date the birth parent or caregiver refused to sign the treatment plan onto the
signature line/document may aid it in showing timely compliance to the
standard.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Corrective Action Plan Compliance

The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this reporting
period. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection
were it received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12327(6) (c) Special evaluation.
• R400.12306 (3)(a)-(f)Application request.
• MCL 722.120(3) Investigation, Inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, record and reports….
• R400.12418(2)(a) & (b) Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) & (h) Initial service plans.
• R400.12420 (1)(g) Updated service plans.
• R400.12604(1)(a), (c), (d) &(g) Orientation and application.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, and Timeframes.
• FOM 722-8 D Treatment plans- Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary- Completion
Requirements.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
• FOM 801-3 Medical Passports.
The agency provided documentation showing proofs of trainings, team meetings
and service plan reviews/discussions at meetings, email reminders to workers
related to these items, and DHS-69 reviews and monitoring, as well as
supervisor/worker supervisory meeting notes showing reviews all as indicated in
the corrective action plan. The agency appears to have implemented or
completed all aspects of its corrective action plan except the hiring of an
administrative assistant by its reported 12/31/2022 date; monitoring treatment plan
signatures via a tracking spreadsheet; a three and seven day plan approach
related to utilizing an administrative assistant staff person in obtaining signatures
on parent agency treatment plan agreements timely, and with the use of Docu-
sign. Also, administrative tracking of adoption orientations, program statement
submissions, and other adoption publications to adoptive families by way of a
spreadsheet. The agency reported the following related to those items: It proved
difficult to hire an administrative assistant prior to May 2023, when this position
was filled; the worker and supervisor continue to monitor treatment plan
signatures during supervisor/worker meetings; Docsign is utilized, but not
consistently because workers continue to take the treatments plan out for
signature during home visits. In terms of the adoption items listed above, the
agency reported workers ensure these documents are provided during the
adoption process; and supervisors discuss this during individual worker/supervisor
meetings, and team meetings.
Notwithstanding the agency’s process on this corrective action plan, they received
repeat violations as indicated in this report.

Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted an annual chief administrator's report dated 8/16/2023. The
report was completed as required, and no concerns were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency provided an annual projected 2022 2023 budget and 9/30/2022
independent financial audit. There were no noted concerns.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to speaking with the chief administrator and program director, two
foster care workers, a licensing worker, foster care supervisor, intake worker, and
two foster care/adoption workers were interviewed. Additionally, two adoptive
families were interviewed. Positive regards were reported for the agency. Areas
of concern centered on a need for additional staff, the workload for staff in general
and a desire for overtime.
The agency does not have youths in independent living, so no youths were
required to be interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the agency's offices and record storage was conducted; no safety issues
or other concerns were observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had two safety alerts this inspection.
Safety Alert # 1
Concern:
Between 5/1/2023 and 6/7/2023 the Division of Child Welfare (DCWL) Analyst
attempted contact with the unlicensed relative. On the latter date the unlicensed
relative refused to participate in the annual audit. The DCWL Analyst notified the
agency of the relative’s refused to participate; and of the agency’s need to make a
home visit to verify the safety of the foster children and the home; ensuring that the
home has the required safety devices (smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detector)
and required housing requirements/fixtures and securements.
Resolution:
The agency completed a visit to the unlicensed relative’s home on 6/8/2023 at
6:00pm. The worker verified a working smoke detector and carbon monoxide
detector located in the home; and provided photos of such. Bedrooms and means of
egress were also verified; along with confirmation of the home having adequate
household equipment, such as beds, running water, sink and toilet. The worker also
confirmed that all walls were permanently affixed, and flooring was acceptable. Photos
were provided related to the latter. Additionally, the worker verified that no weapons,
firearms or ammunition was in the home; cleaning supplies and medications were

not accessible to the children; and the home being free from any health, sanitation
or safety hazards.
Safety Alert # 2
Concern:
No operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy and/or near all sleeping
areas. The smoke detector on the main floor was beeping during the visit. There is a
smoke detector missing near the bedroom where the foster children reside. There is
no smoke detector in the basement.
Resolution:
The agency reported and verified that the foster parent purchased four smoke
detectors from Home Depot. Receipt of the purchases, and photos of the smoke
detectors on each floor of home were provided.
Concern
No operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
The agency reported and verified that the foster parent purchased a carbon
monoxide detector. A receipt of the purchase from Home Depot, along with a photo
showing the device was installed was provided.
Concern:
There was clothing and clutter near the furnace and water heater.
Resolution:
The agency reported and verified that the furnace area was cleaned, and all debris
had been removed. Pictures of the area were provided.
Concern
A bedroom was observed with the door hanging from the hinges.
Resolution:
The agency reported and verified that the foster parent made the doorframe repair.
Pictures were provided showing the door was attached and latchable.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
